member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyProgressRoutine
member.summary: An application-defined callback for some file management. It is called when a portion of a copy or move operation is completed. The LPPROGRESS_ROUTINE type defines a pointer to this callback function. CopyProgressRoutine is a placeholder for the application-defined function name.
member.param: The total size of the file, in bytes.
The total number of bytes transferred from the source file to the destination file since the copy operation began.
The total size of the current file stream, in bytes.
The total number of bytes in the current stream that have been transferred from the source file to the destination file since the copy operation began.
A handle to the current stream. The first time CopyProgressRoutine is called, the stream number is 1.
The reason that was called. This parameter can be one of the values of the enum.
A handle to the source file.
A handle to the destination file.
Argument passed to CopyProgressRoutine by , MoveFileTransacted, or MoveFileWithProgress.
member.returns: The CopyProgressRoutine function should return one of the values of the enum.
member.remarks: An application can use this information to display a progress bar that shows the total number of bytes copied as a percent of the total file size.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes
member.summary: Provides attributes for files and directories.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: The file is read-only. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS. On Linux and macOS, changing the flag is a permissions operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Hidden
member.summary: The file is hidden, and thus is not included in an ordinary directory listing. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.System
member.summary: The file is a system file. That is, the file is part of the operating system or is used exclusively by the operating system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Directory
member.summary: The file is a directory. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Archive
member.summary: This file is marked to be included in incremental backup operation. Windows sets this attribute whenever the file is modified, and backup software should clear it when processing the file during incremental backup.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Device
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Normal
member.summary: The file is a standard file that has no special attributes. This attribute is valid only if it is used alone. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Temporary
member.summary: The file is temporary. A temporary file contains data that is needed while an application is executing but is not needed after the application is finished. File systems try to keep all the data in memory for quicker access rather than flushing the data back to mass storage. A temporary file should be deleted by the application as soon as it is no longer needed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.SparseFile
member.summary: The file is a sparse file. Sparse files are typically large files whose data consists of mostly zeros.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.ReparsePoint
member.summary: The file contains a reparse point, which is a block of user-defined data associated with a file or a directory. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Compressed
member.summary: The file is compressed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Offline
member.summary: The file is offline. The data of the file is not immediately available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.NotContentIndexed
member.summary: The file will not be indexed by the operating system's content indexing service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Encrypted
member.summary: The file or directory is encrypted. For a file, this means that all data in the file is encrypted. For a directory, this means that encryption is the default for newly created files and directories.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.IntegrityStream
member.summary: The file or directory includes data integrity support. When this value is applied to a file, all data streams in the file have integrity support. When this value is applied to a directory, all new files and subdirectories within that directory, by default, include integrity support.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Virtual
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.NoScrubData
member.summary: The file or directory is excluded from the data integrity scan. When this value is applied to a directory, by default, all new files and subdirectories within that directory are excluded from data integrity.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.RecallOnOpen
member.summary: This attribute only appears in directory enumeration classes (FILE_DIRECTORY_INFORMATION, FILE_BOTH_DIR_INFORMATION, etc.). When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory has no physical representation on the local system; the item is virtual. Opening the item will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of it to be fetched from a remote store.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.EA
member.summary: Same as

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.RecallOnDataAccess
member.summary: When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory is not fully present locally. For a file that means that not all of its data is on local storage (e.g. it may be sparse with some data still in remote storage). For a directory it means that some of the directory contents are being virtualized from another location. Reading the file / enumerating the directory will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of the file/directory content to be fetched from a remote store. Only kernel-mode callers can set this bit.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.AddOverlays
member.summary: Apply the appropriate overlays to the file's icon. The flag must also be set. Windows ME or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.AttributesSpecified
member.summary: Modify to indicate that the member of the structure at psfi contains the specific attributes that are desired. These attributes are passed to . If this flag is not specified, 0xFFFFFFFF is passed to , requesting all attributes. This flag cannot be specified with the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.Attributes
member.summary: Retrieve the item attributes. The attributes are copied to the member of the structure specified in the psfi parameter. These are the same attributes that are obtained from .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.DisplayName
member.summary: Retrieve the display name for the file, which is the name as it appears in Windows Explorer. The name is copied to the member of the structure specified in psfi. The returned display name uses the long file name, if there is one, rather than the 8.3 form of the file name. Note that the display name can be affected by settings such as whether extensions are shown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.ExeType
member.summary: Retrieve the type of the executable file if pszPath identifies an executable file. The information is packed into the return value. This flag cannot be specified with any other flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.Icon
member.summary: Retrieve the handle to the icon that represents the file and the index of the icon within the system image list. The handle is copied to the member of the structure specified by psfi, and the index is copied to the member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.IconLocation
member.summary: Retrieve the name of the file that contains the icon representing the file specified by pszPath, as returned by the method of the file's icon handler. Also retrieve the icon index within that file. The name of the file containing the icon is copied to the member of the structure specified by psfi. The icon's index is copied to that structure's member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.LargeIcon
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to retrieve the file's large icon. The flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.LinkOverlay
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to add the link overlay to the file's icon. The flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.OpenIcon
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to retrieve the file's open icon. Also used to modify , causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains the file's small open icon. A container object displays an open icon to indicate that the container is open. The and/or flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.OverlayIndex
member.summary: Return the index of the overlay icon. The value of the overlay index is returned in the upper eight bits of the member of the structure specified by psfi. This flag requires that the be set as well. Windows ME or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.PIDL
member.summary: Indicate that pszPath is the address of an structure rather than a path name.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.Selected
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to blend the file's icon with the system highlight color. The flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.ShelliconSize
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to retrieve a Shell-sized icon. If this flag is not specified the function sizes the icon according to the system metric values. The flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.SmallIcon
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to retrieve the file's small icon. Also used to modify , causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains small icon images. The and/or flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.SysIconIndex
member.summary: Retrieve the index of a system image list icon. If successful, the index is copied to the member of psfi. The return value is a handle to the system image list. Only those images whose indices are successfully copied to iIcon are valid. Attempting to access other images in the system image list will result in undefined behavior.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.TypeName
member.summary: Retrieve the string that describes the file's type. The string is copied to the member of the structure specified in psfi.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.UseFileAttributes
member.summary: Indicates that the function should not attempt to access the file specified by pszPath. Rather, it should act as if the file specified by pszPath exists with the file attributes passed in dwFileAttributes. This flag cannot be combined with the , , or flags.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions
member.summary: Indicate flags that modify the property store object retrieved by methods that create a property store, such as IShellItem2::GetPropertyStore or IPropertyStoreFactory::GetPropertyStore.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.Default
member.summary: Meaning to a calling process: Return a read-only property store that contains all properties. Slow items (offline files) are not opened. Combination with other flags: Can be overridden by other flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.HandlePropertiesOnly
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Include only properties directly from the property handler, which opens the file on the disk, network, or device. Meaning to a file folder: Only include properties directly from the handler.
Meaning to other folders: When delegating to a file folder, pass this flag on to the file folder; do not do any multiplexing (MUX). When not delegating to a file folder, ignore this flag instead of returning a failure code.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY, or GPS_BESTEFFORT.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.ReadWrite
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Can write properties to the item. Note: The store may contain fewer properties than a read-only store.
Meaning to a file folder: ReadWrite.
Meaning to other folders: ReadWrite. Note: When using default MUX, return a single unmultiplexed store because the default MUX does not support ReadWrite.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY, GPS_BESTEFFORT, or GPS_DELAYCREATION. Implies GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.Temporary
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Provides a writable store, with no initial properties, that exists for the lifetime of the Shell item instance; basically, a property bag attached to the item instance.
Meaning to a file folder: Not applicable. Handled by the Shell item.
Meaning to other folders: Not applicable. Handled by the Shell item.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with any other flag. Implies GPS_READWRITE

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.FastPropertiesOnly
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Provides a store that does not involve reading from the disk or network. Note: Some values may be different, or missing, compared to a store without this flag.
Meaning to a file folder: Include the "innate" and "fallback" stores only. Do not load the handler.
Meaning to other folders: Include only properties that are available in memory or can be computed very quickly (no properties from disk, network, or peripheral IO devices). This is normally only data sources from the IDLIST. When delegating to other folders, pass this flag on to them.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_READWRITE, GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY, or GPS_DELAYCREATION.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.OpensLowItem
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Open a slow item (offline file) if necessary. Meaning to a file folder: Retrieve a file from offline storage, if necessary. Note: Without this flag, the handler is not created for offline files.
Meaning to other folders: Do not return any properties that are very slow.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY or GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.DelayCreation
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Delay memory-intensive operations, such as file access, until a property is requested that requires such access.
Meaning to a file folder: Do not create the handler until needed; for example, either GetCount/GetAt or GetValue, where the innate store does not satisfy the request. Note: GetValue might fail due to file access problems.
Meaning to other folders: If the folder has memory-intensive properties, such as delegating to a file folder or network access, it can optimize performance by supporting IDelayedPropertyStoreFactory and splitting up its properties into a fast and a slow store. It can then use delayed MUX to recombine them.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY or GPS_READWRITE

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.BestEffort
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Succeed at getting the store, even if some properties are not returned. Note: Some values may be different, or missing, compared to a store without this flag.
Meaning to a file folder: Succeed and return a store, even if the handler or innate store has an error during creation. Only fail if substores fail.
Meaning to other folders: Succeed on getting the store, even if some properties are not returned.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_READWRITE, or GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.GetPropertyStoreOptions.MaskValid
member.summary: Mask for valid GETPROPERTYSTOREFLAGS values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanCopy
member.summary: The specified items can be copied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanMove
member.summary: The specified items can be moved.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanLink
member.summary: Shortcuts can be created for the specified items. This flag has the same value as DROPEFFECT. The normal use of this flag is to add a Create Shortcut item to the shortcut menu that is displayed during drag-and-drop operations. However, SFGAO_CANLINK also adds a Create Shortcut item to the Microsoft Windows Explorer's File menu and to normal shortcut menus. If this item is selected, your application's IContextMenu::InvokeCommand is invoked with the lpVerb member of the CMINVOKECOMMANDINFO structure set to "link." Your application is responsible for creating the link.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Storage
member.summary: The specified items can be bound to an IStorage interface through IShellFolder::BindToObject.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanRename
member.summary: The specified items can be renamed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanDelete
member.summary: The specified items can be deleted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.HasPropertySheet
member.summary: The specified items have property sheets.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.DropTarget
member.summary: The specified items are drop targets.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CapabilityMask

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.System
member.summary: Windows 7 and later. The specified items are system items.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Encrypted
member.summary: The specified items are encrypted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.IsSlow
member.summary: Indicates that accessing the object = through IStream or other storage interfaces, is a slow operation. Applications should avoid accessing items flagged with SFGAO_ISSLOW.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Ghosted
member.summary: The specified items are ghosted icons.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Link
member.summary: The specified items are shortcuts.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Share

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.ReadOnly

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Hidden
member.summary: The item is hidden and should not be displayed unless the Show hidden files and folders option is enabled in Folder Settings.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.DisplayAttributeMask
member.summary: This flag is a mask for the display attributes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.FileSystemAncestor
member.summary: The specified folders contain one or more file system folders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Folder
member.summary: The specified items are folders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.FileSystem
member.summary: The specified folders or file objects are part of the file system that is, they are files, directories, or root directories).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.HasSubFolder
member.summary: The specified folders have subfolders = and are, therefore, expandable in the left pane of Windows Explorer).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.ContentsMask
member.summary: This flag is a mask for the contents attributes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Validate
member.summary: When specified as input, SFGAO_VALIDATE instructs the folder to validate that the items pointed to by the contents of apidl exist. If one or more of those items do not exist, IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf returns a failure code. When used with the file system folder, SFGAO_VALIDATE instructs the folder to discard cached properties retrieved by clients of IShellFolder2::GetDetailsEx that may have accumulated for the specified items.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Removable
member.summary: The specified items are on removable media or are themselves removable devices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Compressed
member.summary: The specified items are compressed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Browsable
member.summary: The specified items can be browsed in place.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Nonenumerated
member.summary: The items are nonenumerated items.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.NewContent
member.summary: The objects contain new content.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.CanMoniker
member.summary: It is possible to create monikers for the specified file objects or folders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.HasStorage

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.ShellFileGetAttributesOptions.Stream

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO
member.summary: Contains information about a file object.
member.remarks: This structure is used with the function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO.hIcon
member.summary: A handle to the icon that represents the file. You are responsible for destroying this handle with DestroyIcon when you no longer need it.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO.iIcon
member.summary: The index of the icon image within the system image list.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO.dwAttributes
member.summary: An array of values that indicates the attributes of the file object. For information about these values, see the method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO.szDisplayName
member.summary: A string that contains the name of the file as it appears in the Windows Shell, or the path and file name of the file that contains the icon representing the file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.SHFILEINFO.szTypeName
member.summary: A string that describes the type of file.
Retrieves information about an object in the file system, such as a file, folder, directory, or drive root.

param.name: pszPath
param.para: A string of maximum length that contains the path and file name. Both absolute and relative paths are valid.

If the uFlags parameter includes the flag, this parameter must be the address of an ITEMIDLIST(PIDL) structure that contains the list of item identifiers that uniquely identifies the file within the Shell's namespace. The PIDL must be a fully qualified PIDL. Relative PIDLs are not allowed.

If the uFlags parameter includes the flag, this parameter does not have to be a valid file name. The function will proceed as if the file exists with the specified name and with the file attributes passed in the dwFileAttributes parameter. This allows you to obtain information about a file type by passing just the extension for pszPath and passing in dwFileAttributes.
This string can use either short (the 8.3 form) or long file names.

member.param: A combination of one or more flags. If uFlags does not include the flag, this parameter is ignored.
A structure to receive the file information.
The size, in bytes, of the structure pointed to by the psfi parameter.
The flags that specify the file information to retrieve. This parameter can be a combination of the values of the enum.
member.returns:
Returns a value whose meaning depends on the uFlags parameter.
If uFlags does not contain or , the return value is nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.
If uFlags contains the flag, the return value specifies the type of the executable file. It will be one of the following values. Return code | Description -----------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------ 0 | Nonexecutable file or an error condition. LOWORD = NE or PE and HIWORD = Windows version | Windows application. LOWORD = MZ and HIWORD = 0 | MS-DOS.exe or .com file LOWORD = PE and HIWORD = 0 | Console application or.bat file

remarks.para: You should call this function from a background thread. Failure to do so could cause the UI to stop responding.
If returns an icon handle in the hIcon member of the structure pointed to by psfi, you are responsible for freeing it with when you no longer need it.

Note: Once you have a handle to a system image list, you can use the Image List API to manipulate it like any other image list. Because system image lists are created on a per-process basis, you should treat them as read-only objects. Writing to a system image list may overwrite or delete one of the system images, making it unavailable or incorrect for the remainder of the process.

When you use the flag with a Windows application, the Windows version of the executable is given in the HIWORD of the return value. This version is returned as a hexadecimal value. For details on equating this value with a specific Windows version, see Using the Windows Headers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellNativeMethods.CopyFileEx(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyProgressRoutine,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags)

summary.para: Copies an existing file to a new file, notifying the application of its progress through a callback function.
To perform this operation as a transacted operation, use the CopyFileTransacted function.

param.name: lpExistingFileName
param.para: The name of an existing file.

In the ANSI version of this function, the name is limited to MAX_PATH characters. To extend this limit to 32,767 wide characters, call the Unicode version of the function and prepend "\?" to the path.For more information, see Naming a File.

Tip Starting in Windows 10, version 1607, for the unicode version of this function (CopyFileExW), you can opt-in to remove the MAX_PATH character limitation without prepending "\\?\". See the "Maximum Path Limitation" section of Naming Files, Paths, and Namespaces for details.
If lpExistingFileName does not exist, the function fails, and the function returns .

param.name: lpNewFileName
param.para: The name of the new file.

In the ANSI version of this function, the name is limited to MAX_PATH characters. To extend this limit to 32,767 wide characters, call the Unicode version of the function and prepend "\?" to the path.For more information, see Naming a File.

Tip Starting inWindows 10, version 1607, for the unicode version of this function (CopyFileExW), you can opt-in to remove the MAX_PATH character limitation without prepending "\\?\". See the "Maximum Path Limitation" section of Naming Files, Paths, and Namespaces for details.

member.param: The address of a callback function of type that is called each time another portion of the file has been copied. This parameter can be . For more information on the progress callback function, see the function.
The argument to be passed to the callback function. This parameter can be .
If this flag is set to during the copy operation, the operation is canceled. Otherwise, the copy operation will continue to completion.
Flags that specify how the file is to be copied. This parameter can be a combination of the enum.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero.To get extended error information call .
If lpProgressRoutine returns due to the user canceling the operation, will return zero and will return . In this case, the partially copied destination file is deleted.
If lpProgressRoutine returns due to the user stopping the operation, will return zero and will return . In this case, the partially copied destination file is left intact.

member.remarks:
This function preserves extended attributes, OLE structured storage, NTFS file system alternate data streams, security resource attributes, and file attributes.
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: Security resource attributes (ATTRIBUTE_SECURITY_INFORMATION) for the existing file are not copied to the new file until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.
The security resource properties(ATTRIBUTE_SECURITY_INFORMATION) for the existing file are copied to the new file.
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: Security resource properties for the existing file are not copied to the new file until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.
This function fails with if the destination file already exists and has the or attribute set.
When encrypted files are copied using , the function attempts to encrypt the destination file with the keys used in the encryption of the source file.If this cannot be done, this function attempts to encrypt the destination file with default keys.If both of these methods cannot be done, fails with an error code. If you want to complete the copy operation even if the destination file cannot be encrypted, include the as the value of the dwCopyFlags parameter in your call to .
If is specified, the following rules apply:
If the source file is a symbolic link, the symbolic link is copied, not the target file. If the source file is not a symbolic link, there is no change in behavior. If the destination file is an existing symbolic link, the symbolic link is overwritten, not the target file. If is also specified, and the destination file is an existing symbolic link, the operation fails in all cases.
If is not specified, the following rules apply:
If is also specified, and the destination file is an existing symbolic link, the operation fails only if the target of the symbolic link exists. If is not specified, there is no change in behavior.
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: If you are writing an application that is optimizing file copy operations across a LAN, consider using the TransmitFile function from Windows Sockets(Winsock). TransmitFile supports high-performance network transfers and provides a simple interface to send the contents of a file to a remote computer.To use TransmitFile, you must write a Winsock client application that sends the file from the source computer as well as a Winsock server application that uses other Winsock functions to receive the file on the remote computer.
In Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012, this function is supported by the following technologies. Technology Supported Server Message Block (SMB) 3.0 protocol Yes SMB 3.0 Transparent Failover (TFO) Yes SMB 3.0 with Scale-out File Shares (SO) Yes Cluster Shared Volume File System (CsvFS) Yes Resilient File System (ReFS) Yes

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes
member.summary:
The STGM constants are flags that indicate conditions for creating and deleting the object and access modes for the object.
You can combine these flags, but you can only choose one flag from each group of related flags. Typically one flag from each of the access and sharing groups must be specified for all functions and methods which use these constants.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Direct
member.summary: Indicates that, in direct mode, each change to a storage or stream element is written as it occurs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Transacted
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, changes are buffered and written only if an explicit commit operation is called.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Simple
member.summary: Provides a faster implementation of a compound file in a limited, but frequently used, case.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Read
member.summary: Indicates that the object is read-only, meaning that modifications cannot be made.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Write
member.summary: Enables you to save changes to the object, but does not permit access to its data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.ReadWrite
member.summary: Enables access and modification of object data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.ShareDenyNone
member.summary: Specifies that subsequent openings of the object are not denied read or write access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.ShareDenyRead
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in Read mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.ShareDenyWrite
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object for Write or ReadWrite access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.ShareExclusive
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in any mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Priority
member.summary: Opens the storage object with exclusive access to the most recently committed version.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.DeleteOnRelease
member.summary: Indicates that the underlying file is to be automatically destroyed when the root storage object is released. This feature is most useful for creating temporary files.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.NoScratch
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, a temporary scratch file is usually used to save modifications until the Commit method is called. Specifying NoScratch permits the unused portion of the original file to be used as work space instead of creating a new file for that purpose.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Create
member.summary: Indicates that an existing storage object or stream should be removed before the new object replaces it.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.Convert
member.summary: Creates the new object while preserving existing data in a stream named "Contents".

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.FailIfThere
member.summary: Causes the create operation to fail if an existing object with the specified name exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.NoSnapshot
member.summary: This flag is used when opening a storage object with Transacted and without ShareExclusive or ShareDenyWrite. In this case, specifying NoSnapshot prevents the system-provided implementation from creating a snapshot copy of the file. Instead, changes to the file are written to the end of the file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.AccessModes.DirectSingleWriterMultipleReader
member.summary: Supports direct mode for single-writer, multireader file operations.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption
member.summary: Represents the different retrieval options for the thumbnail or icon, such as extracting the thumbnail or icon from a file, from the cache only, or from memory only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.Default
member.summary: The default behavior loads a thumbnail. If there is no thumbnail for the current ShellItem, the icon is retrieved. The thumbnail or icon is extracted if it is not currently cached.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.CacheOnly
member.summary: The CacheOnly behavior returns a cached thumbnail if it is available. Allows access to the disk, but only to retrieve a cached item. If no cached thumbnail is available, a cached per-instance icon is returned but a thumbnail or icon is not extracted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.MemoryOnly
member.summary: The MemoryOnly behavior returns the item only if it is in memory. The disk is not accessed even if the item is cached. Note that this only returns an already-cached icon and can fall back to a per-class icon if an item has a per-instance icon that has not been cached yet. Retrieving a thumbnail, even if it is cached, always requires the disk to be accessed, so this method should not be called from the user interface (UI) thread without passing ShellThumbnailCacheOptions.MemoryOnly.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption
member.summary: Represents the format options for the thumbnails and icons.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.Default
member.summary: The default behavior loads a thumbnail. An HBITMAP for the icon of the item is retrieved if there is no thumbnail for the current Shell Item.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.ThumbnailOnly
member.summary: The ThumbnailOnly behavior returns only the thumbnails, never the icon. Note that not all items have thumbnails so ShellThumbnailFormatOption.ThumbnailOnly can fail in these cases.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.IconOnly
member.summary: The IconOnly behavior returns only the icon, never the thumbnail.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Border
member.summary: The window has a thin-line border.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Caption
member.summary: The window has a title bar (includes the WS_BORDER style).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Child
member.summary: The window is a child window. A window with this style cannot have a menu bar. This style cannot be used with the WS_POPUP style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.ChildWindow
member.summary: Same as the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.ClipChildren
member.summary: Excludes the area occupied by child windows when drawing occurs within the parent window. This style is used when creating the parent window.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.ClipSiblings
member.summary: Clips child windows relative to each other; that is, when a particular child window receives a WM_PAINT message, the WS_CLIPSIBLINGS style clips all other overlapping child windows out of the region of the child window to be updated. If WS_CLIPSIBLINGS is not specified and child windows overlap, it is possible, when drawing within the client area of a child window, to draw within the client area of a neighboring child window.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Disabled
member.summary: The window is initially disabled. A disabled window cannot receive input from the user. To change this after a window has been created, use the EnableWindow function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.DialogFrame
member.summary: The window has a border of a style typically used with dialog boxes. A window with this style cannot have a title bar.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Group
member.summary:
The window is the first control of a group of controls. The group consists of this first control and all controls defined after it, up to the next control with the WS_GROUP style. The first control in each group usually has the WS_TABSTOP style so that the user can move from group to group. The user can subsequently change the keyboard focus from one control in the group to the next control in the group by using the direction keys.
You can turn this style on and off to change dialog box navigation. To change this style after a window has been created, use the SetWindowLong function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.HorizontalScroll
member.summary: The window has a horizontal scroll bar.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Iconic
member.summary: The window is initially minimized. Same as the WS_MINIMIZE style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Maximize
member.summary: The window is initially maximized.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.MaximizeBox
member.summary: The window has a maximize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specifie

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Minimize
member.summary: The window is initially minimized. Same as the WS_ICONIC style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.MinimizeBox
member.summary: The window has a minimize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Overlapped
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the WS_TILED style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Popup
member.summary: The windows is a pop-up window. This style cannot be used with the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.SizeBox
member.summary: The window has a sizing border. Same as the WS_THICKFRAME style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.SystemMenu
member.summary: The window has a window menu on its title bar. The WS_CAPTION style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Tabstop
member.summary:
The window is a control that can receive the keyboard focus when the user presses the TAB key. Pressing the TAB key changes the keyboard focus to the next control with the WS_TABSTOP style.
You can turn this style on and off to change dialog box navigation. To change this style after a window has been created, use the SetWindowLong function. For user-created windows and modeless dialogs to work with tab stops, alter the message loop to call the IsDialogMessage function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.ThickFrame
member.summary: The window has a sizing border. Same as the WS_SIZEBOX style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Tiled
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the WS_OVERLAPPED style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.Visible
member.summary:
The window is initially visible.
This style can be turned on and off by using the ShowWindow or SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.VerticalScroll
member.summary: The window has a vertical scroll bar.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.TiledWindowMask
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. Same as the WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW style.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.PopupWindowMask
member.summary: The window is a pop-up window. The WS_CAPTION and WS_POPUPWINDOW styles must be combined to make the window menu visible.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.WindowStyles.OverlappedWindowMask
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. Same as the WS_TILEDWINDOW style.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManagerNativeMethods.EnableCustomWindowPreview(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Call this method to either enable custom previews on the taskbar (second argument as true) or to disable (second argument as false). If called with True, the method will call DwmSetWindowAttribute for the specific window handle and let DWM know that we will be providing a custom bitmap for the thumbnail as well as Aero peek.

The bridge dispatches the request to the correct function (GetWindowLong in 32-bit mode and GetWindowLongPtr in 64-bit mode).

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DefinitionOptions.None
member.summary: No behaviors are defined.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DefinitionOptions.LocalRedirectOnly
member.summary: Prevents a per-user known folder from being redirected to a network location.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DefinitionOptions.Roamable
member.summary: The known folder can be roamed through PC-to-PC synchronization.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DefinitionOptions.Precreate
member.summary: Creates the known folder when the user first logs on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory
member.summary: Specifies the categories for known folders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.None
member.summary: The folder category is not specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Virtual
member.summary: The folder is a virtual folder. Virtual folders are not part of the file system. For example, Control Panel and Printers are virtual folders. A number of properties such as folder path and redirection do not apply to this category.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Fixed
member.summary: The folder is fixed. Fixed file system folders are not managed by the Shell and are usually given a permanent path when the system is installed. For example, the Windows and Program Files folders are fixed folders. A number of properties such as redirection do not apply to this category.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Common
member.summary: The folder is a common folder. Common folders are used for sharing data and settings accessible by all users of a system. For example, all users share a common Documents folder as well as their per-user Documents folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.PerUser
member.summary: Each user has their own copy of the folder. Per-user folders are those stored under each user's profile and accessible only by that user.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderProperties
member.summary: Structure used publicly to store property values for a known folder. This structure holds the information returned in the FOLDER_DEFINITION structure, and resources referenced by fields in NativeFolderDefinition, such as icon and tool tip.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderIdentifiers
member.summary: Contains the GUID identifiers for well-known folders.

member.summary: Returns the friendly name for a specified folder.

member.returns: A value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderIdentifiers.GetAllFolders

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderTypes
member.summary: The FolderTypes values represent a view template applied to a folder, usually based on its intended use and contents.

member.summary: Internal class that contains interop declarations for functions that are considered benign but that are performance critical.
member.remarks: Functions that are benign but not performance critical should be located in the NativeMethods class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.None
member.summary: Redirection capability is unknown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.AllowAll
member.summary: The known folder can be redirected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.Redirectable

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.DenyAll
member.summary: Redirection is not allowed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.DenyPolicy
member.summary: The folder cannot be redirected because the policy prohibits redirecting this folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.RedirectionCapability.DenyPermissions
member.summary: The folder cannot be redirected because the calling application does not have sufficient permissions.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes
member.summary: Describes the event that has occurred. Typically, only one event is specified at a time. If more than one event is specified, the values contained in the dwItem1 and dwItem2 parameters must be the same, respectively, for all specified events. This parameter can be one or more of the following values:

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemRename
member.summary: The name of a nonfolder item has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the previous PIDL or name of the item. dwItem2 contains the new PIDL or name of the item.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemCreate
member.summary: A nonfolder item has been created. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that was created. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemDelete
member.summary: A nonfolder item has been deleted. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that was deleted. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryCreate
member.summary: A folder has been created. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that was created. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryDelete
member.summary: A folder has been removed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.MediaInsert
member.summary: Storage media has been inserted into a drive. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that contains the new media. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.MediaRemove
member.summary: Storage media has been removed from a drive. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive from which the media was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DriveRemove
member.summary: A drive has been removed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DriveAdd
member.summary: A drive has been added. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that was added. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.NetShare
member.summary: A folder on the local computer is being shared via the network. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that is being shared. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.NetUnshare
member.summary: A folder on the local computer is no longer being shared via the network. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that is no longer being shared. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AttributesChange
member.summary: The attributes of an item or folder have changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item or folder that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryContentsUpdate
member.summary: The contents of an existing folder have changed, but the folder still exists and has not been renamed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL. If a folder has been created, deleted, or renamed, use SHCNE_MKDIR, SHCNE_RMDIR, or SHCNE_RENAMEFOLDER, respectively.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.Update
member.summary: An existing item (a folder or a nonfolder) has changed, but the item still exists and has not been renamed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL. If a nonfolder item has been created, deleted, or renamed, use SHCNE_CREATE, SHCNE_DELETE, or SHCNE_RENAMEITEM, respectively, instead.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ServerDisconnect
member.summary: The computer has disconnected from a server. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the server from which the computer was disconnected. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

members.member: An image in the system image list has changed. SHCNF_DWORD must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 is not used and should be NULL. dwItem2 contains the index in the system image list that has changed. //verify this is not opposite?

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryRename
member.summary: The name of a folder has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the previous PIDL or name of the folder. dwItem2 contains the new PIDL or name of the folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.FreeSpace
member.summary: The amount of free space on a drive has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive on which the free space changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AssociationChange
member.summary: A file type association has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST must be specified in the uFlags parameter. dwItem1 and dwItem2 are not used and must be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DiskEventsMask
member.summary: Specifies a combination of all of the disk event identifiers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.GlobalEventsMask
member.summary: Specifies a combination of all of the global event identifiers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AllEventsMask
member.summary: All events have occurred.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.FromInterrupt
member.summary: The specified event occurred as a result of a system interrupt. As this value modifies other event values, it cannot be used alone.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Controls.IExplorerBrowser.Initialize(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NativeRect@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Controls.FolderSettings)
member.summary: Prepares the browser to be navigated.
member.param: A handle to the owner window or control.

A pointer to a RECT containing the coordinates of the bounding rectangle the browser will occupy. The coordinates are relative to hwndParent. If this parameter is NULL, then method IExplorerBrowser::SetRect should subsequently be called.

A pointer to a FOLDERSETTINGS structure that determines how the folder will be displayed in the view. If this parameter is NULL, then method IExplorerBrowser::SetFolderSettings should be called, otherwise, the default view settings for the folder are used.

member.summary: Initiates a connection with IExplorerBrowser for event callbacks.

When this method returns, contains a token that uniquely identifies the event listener. This allows several event listeners to be subscribed at a time.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageFilterAction
member.summary: The action to be performed by the .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageFilterAction.Reset
member.summary: Resets the window message filter for hWnd to the default. Any message allowed globally or process-wide will get through, but any message not included in those two categories, and which comes from a lower privileged process, will be blocked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageFilterAction.Allow
member.summary: Allows the message through the filter. This enables the message to be received by hWnd, regardless of the source of the message, even it comes from a lower privileged process.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageFilterAction.Disallow
member.summary: Blocks the message to be delivered to hWnd if it comes from a lower privileged process, unless the message is allowed process-wide by using the ChangeWindowMessageFilter function or globally.

member.summary: The message has already been allowed by this window's message filter, and the function thus succeeded with no change to the window's message filter. Applies to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageResultInfo.AlreadyDisallowedForWindow
member.summary: The message has already been blocked by this window's message filter, and the function thus succeeded with no change to the window's message filter. Applies to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Taskbar.MessageResultInfo.AllowedHigher

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.MediaDevices.FormatCode
member.summary: The enumeration type defines a list of format codes that describe types of content transferred to and from a device.

remarks.para: To discover the formats supported by a device, an application can use to query the g_wszWMDMFormatsSupported device property.
To discover device capabilities for a particular format, an application can call .
An application can set the format code while creating a storage on device by including the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property in metadata passed in the pMetaData parameter of a call to .
An application can query the format code of a storage by calling or and retrieving the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property.

If the device supports setting the format code after the creation of storage, an application can use to set the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property. Some devices may not allow changing the format code after the storage is created on the device. Therefore, setting this property along with the metadata passed in is strongly recommended.

member.summary: Must be set to a format or formats supported by the device. Note that previous versions of the Windows Media Device Manager recommended using WMDM_WAVE_FORMAT_ALL to indicate support for all formats. However, this is no longer recommended, as different media players will interpret this in different ways, and few devices can truly play any file format. It is now recommended that you use the value of the enumeration, or better yet specify a range of formats with the structure.

member.summary: The method retrieves the next one or more object IDs in the enumeration sequence.
member.param: A count of the objects requested.
An array of s, each specifying a retrieved object ID. The caller must allocate an array of elements. The caller must free both the array and the returned strings. The strings are freed by calling .
On input, this parameter is ignored. On output, the number of IDs actually retrieved. If no object IDs are released and the return value is , there are no more objects to enumerate.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.remarks: If fewer than the requested number of elements remain in the sequence, this method retrieves the remaining elements. The number of elements that are actually retrieved is returned through pcFetched (unless the caller passed in NULL for that parameter). Enumerated objects are all peersthat is, enumerating children of an object will enumerate only direct children, not grandchild or deeper objects.

member.summary: The method cancels a pending operation.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

summary.para: The interface provides access to a portable device.
To create and open this interface, first call with or to retrieve an interface, and then call to open a connection to the device.

remarks.para: The client interfaces are designed to be used for any WPD object; it is not necessary to create a new instance for each object referenced by the application. After an application opens an instance of the interface, it should open and cache any other WPD client interfaces that it will require.

For Windows 7, supports two CLSIDs for . returns an pointer that does not aggregate the free-threaded marshaler; is a new CLSID that returns an pointer that aggregates the free-threaded marshaler.Both pointers support the same functionality otherwise.
Applications that live in Single Threaded Apartments should use as this eliminates the overhead of interface pointer marshaling. is still supported for legacy applications.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Open(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method opens a connection between the application and the device.
member.param: A reference to a null-terminated string that contains the Plug and Play ID string for the device. You can get this string by calling .

param.name: pClientInfo
param.para: A reference to an interface that holds information that identifies the application to the device. This interface holds PROPERTYKEY/value pairs that try to identify an application uniquely. Although the presence of a CoCreated interface is required, the application is not required to send any key/value pairs. However, sending data might improve performance. Typical key/value pairs include the application name, major and minor version, and build number.
See properties beginning with "WPD_CLIENT_" in the Properties section.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: A device must be opened before you can call any methods on it. (Note that the methods do not require you to open a device before calling any methods.) However, usually you do not need to call .

Administrators can restrict the access of portable devices to computers running on a network.For example, an administrator may restrict all Guest users to read-only access, while Authenticated users are given read/write access.

Due to these security issues, if your application will not perform write operations, it should call the method and request read-only access by specifying GENERIC_READ for the WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property that it supplies in the pClientInfo parameter.

If your application requires write operations, it should call the method as shown in the following example code. The first time, it should request read/write access by passing the default WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property in the pClientInfo parameter.If this first call fails and returns E_ACCESSDENIED, your application should call the method a second time and request read-only access by specifying GENERIC_READ for the WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property that it supplies in the pClientInfo parameter.
Applications that live in Single Threaded Apartments should use , as this eliminates the overhead of interface pointer marshaling. is still supported for legacy applications.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.SendCommand(System.UInt32,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceValues@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method sends a command to the device and retrieves the results synchronously.
member.param: Currently not used; specify zero.

param.name: pParameters
param.para: Reference to an interface that specifies the command and parameters to call on the device. This interface must include the following two values to indicate the command. Additional parameters vary depending on the command. For a list of the parameters that are required for each command, see Commands.

member.param: Address of a variable that receives a pointer to an interface that indicates the results of the command results, including success or failure, and any command values returned by the device. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it. The retrieved values vary by command; see the appropriate command documentation in Commands to learn what values are returned by each command call.

returns.para: The returned value indicates success or failure to send a command and return a result from the driver; it does not indicate whether the driver supports the command or if it encountered some error in processing the command. (For more information, see Remarks.) These errors are returned in the values of the parameter. The possible values returned by this method include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.param: Address of a variable that receives a pointer to an interface that is used to access the content on a device. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

member.param: A variable that receives a reference to an interface that can describe the device's capabilities. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Cancel
member.summary: The method cancels a pending operation on this interface.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: If your application invokes the WPD API from multiple threads, each thread should create a new instance of the interface. Doing this ensures that any cancel operation affects only the I/O for the affected thread.

If an write operation is underway when the method is invoked, your application should discard all changes by invoking the method. Once the changes are discarded, the application should also close the stream by invoking the IUnknown.Release method.
Also, note that if the method is invoked before an method has completed, the data being written may be corrupted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Close
member.summary: The method closes the connection with the device.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.remarks: You should not usually need to call this method yourself. When the last reference to the interface is released, Windows Portable Devices calls for you. Calling this method manually forces the connection to the device to close, and any Windows Portable Devices objects hosted on this device will cease to function. You can call to reopen the connection.
